text: The Women's Baltic Cup is a women's association football tournament contested between the Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, usually every year. They can also invite other teams to participate, like they did in 2016, when the Faroe Islands were invited. The tournament is the women's equivalent of the men's Baltic Cup. ==Results== {|class="wikitable" !width="80px"| Year!!width="90px"| Host !!width="160px"| Champions !!width="160px"| Runners- up!!width="160px"| Third place!!width="160px"| Fourth place |- |align="center"| 1996 || Telsiai || || || ||rowspan=16| |- |align="center"| 1997 || Viljandi || || || |- |align="center"| 1998 || Riga || || || |- |align="center"| 2003 || Pärnu || || || |- |align="center"| 2004 || Ukmerge || || || |- |align="center"| 2005 || Ventspils || || || |- |align="center"| 2006 || Pärnu || || || |- |align="center"| 2007 || Siauliai || || || |- |align="center"| 2008 || Valmiera || || || |- |align="center"| 2009 || Põlva || || || |align="center"| 2010 || Šiauliai || || || |align="center"| 2011 || Staicele || || || |align="center"| 2012 || Tartu || || || |align="center"| 2013 || Vilnius || || || |align="center"| 2014 || Šiauliai || || || |- |align="center"| 2015 || Tallinn || || || |- |align="center"| 2016 || Riga || || || || |- |align="center"| 2017|| Šiauliai || || || ||rowspan=3| |- |align="center"| 2018|| Tallinn || || || |- |align="center"| 2019|| Riga || || || |} ==Medal summary== As of 2019. ==See also== * Baltic Cup * Baltic Futsal Cup * Women's Baltic Football League ==References== ==External links== Category:Baltic Cup (football) Category:International women's association football invitational tournaments Category:Recurring sporting events established in 1996 Category:1996 establishments in Europe
